posts.name: Allan S. Edford
posts.cooked: 2025 FRC Game Manual list this relay as an approved relay  Looking for a electrical schematic of the control system that would highlite it’s interface with Rio relay port and relayed sensors,actuators, etc Do not fuully understand it’ functionally  why used  ;at this point  if i had to analysis that circuit i would be lost ;there were threads in COTs Relay Board and relay categories but they are closed (2019 )

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked: These are 5V outputs – I didn’t find a current spec, but the relay doesn’t need much at all, only 10mA.  So, I’d connect the ground (⏚) and FWD (or REV) pins from one of the relay outputs to the two input connections on the relay.  I don’t have a good diagram of picture of the relay, but you should connect ground to the relay input with either ground or minus (-).

posts.name: Domtech
posts.cooked:
The relay ports have an A channel(FWD) and a B channel(REV). The intent is that they control an H-bridge relay which is really just 2 relays packaged together such that the A side toggles one wire of a motor between positive and negative power, and the B side toggles the other wire. If A is on(12V) and B is off(0V) then the motor goes forwards, flip those and it goes backwards. If both sides are on or off at the same time then the motor stops.

The only allowed H-bridge relay is the discontinued spike module. Per the blue box under R504:

It looks like the Automation Direct relays are discontinued too now, but they were a low-cost option for single direction control of the smaller motors specified in R505, or for inherently single direction devices like solenoids, electromagnets, LEDs, or air compressors.

As far as how to wire one, the control side gets wired to FWD(or REV) and Ground of a relay port on the RIO, and the other side is used to break or connect 12V power to your chosen device.

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked:
The roboRIO datasheet shows 7.5ma output on the relays (limited by the 680 ohm series resistor). Product Documentation - NI

My assumption is that since that relay is legal, that someone tested it and it was fine activating with the roboRIO current, but I haven’t done it myself.

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked:
MROWL:

Do not fuully understand it’ functionally why used

Are you asking why someone would use a relay in general, or you have a specific use case for a relay, and you’re trying to figure out how to use it?

For the former, very few teams use relays any more, which is also why you’re having trouble finding any discussion. Based on usage reporting only about 1% of teams used relays last year.

link_counts.title: Control System Beta Testing and Usage Reporting

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked: This relay acts like a computer-controlled switch.  It’s similar to what’s inside the PCM that runs the compressor under computer control.  The point of a relay is to allow you to switch more current or a different voltage.  If the load is small, there is a low-current switch port on the REV PH, or the PCM could be an option (check the rules carefully).  If you can find an old SPARK relay module, that makes it pretty easy.  But the main thing to sort out is what you need to control, or to turn on and off.
